R and Armadillo integration using the header-only cpp11 R package

Source: vignettes/motivations.Rmd
motivations.Rmd

Motivations

R and S have a long history of interacting with compiled languages. The original version of S from the late 1970s was a wrapper around FORTRAN routines and R nowadays uses compiled C code, for example, to estimate a linear model coefficients.

Armadillo is a linear algebra library for the C++ language, aiming towards a good balance between speed and ease of use. It is justified in the fact that C++, in its current form, is very valuable to address bottlenecks that we find with interpreted languages such as R and Python but it does not provide data structures nor functions for linear algebra.

RcppArmadillo was first published to CRAN in 2010, and it integrates Rcpp and the Armadillo library, allowin to use Armadillo C++ functions within R.

cpp11 is a ground up rewrite of C++ bindings to R with different design trade-offs and features, and cpp11armadillo aims at providing an additional layer to put the end-user focus on the computation rather than on configuration and setups.

The development of cpp11armadillo emerges from the desire to follow the same design choices as in cpp11, while Rcpp is a prevalent tool for integrating C++ code with R. These design choices are:

  • Implementing copy-on-write semantics to optimize memory usage and ensure more predictable behavior of objects shared between R and C++.
  • Enhancing the safety of utilizing the R API from C++ code, thereby reducing the risk of errors and improving code stability.
  • Adding support for ALTREP objects, which represent a more modern and efficient way of handling R data structures, leading to performance improvements.
  • Standardizing on UTF-8 strings to ensure consistent handling of text data across various platforms and locales, thereby facilitating internationalization.
  • Incorporating newer C++11 features to leverage advancements in the C++ language that enhance code clarity, simplicity, and performance.
  • Providing a simpler implementation that makes the library easier to understand, maintain, and extend, benefiting both current users and future contributors.
  • Achieving faster compilation times and lower memory requirements, making the development process more efficient, especially for large projects.
  • Offering a completely header-only approach, eliminating Application Binary Interface compatibility issues and simplifying library integration and distribution.
  • Facilitating vendoring, which allows for the inclusion of the library directly in projects, thus simplifying dependency management and distribution.
  • Implementing a more efficient linked list data structure for robust protection, improving memory management and object lifecycle handling within the R environment.
  • Enabling more efficient growth of vectors, optimizing operations that involve dynamic data structures and enhancing performance for data manipulation tasks.

These developments reflect a comprehensive effort to provide a modern, efficient, and safe interface for integrating C++ and R that aligns with the Tidy philosophy, addressing both the technical and community-driven aspects that influence software evolution.

Benchmarks

I tried to benchmark the eigenvalues function to test for speed and memory allocation in cpp11armadillo and RcppArmadillo.

R code:

# create a matrix of 100x100, ...,  1,000,000x1,000,000
mat <- list()

for (i in 1:3) {
  set.seed(200100)
  mat[[i]] <- matrix(runif(10^(i + 1) * 10^(i + 1)), ncol = 10^(i + 1))
  mat[[i]] <- mat[[i]] + t(mat[[i]])
}

# benchmark eigen decomposition
bench::mark(
  cpp11armadillotest:::eigen_sym_mat(mat[[1]]),
  rcpparmadillotest:::eigen_sym_mat(mat[[1]])
)

cpp11armadillo code:

#include <armadillo.hpp>
#include <cpp11.hpp>
#include <cpp11armadillo.hpp>

using namespace arma;
using namespace cpp11;

doubles_matrix<> eigen_sym_mat(const doubles_matrix<>& x) {
  Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);

  Mat<double> y = eig_sym(X);

  return as_doubles_matrix(y);
}

RcppArmadillo code:

#include <RcppArmadillo.h>
// [[Rcpp::depends(RcppArmadillo)]]

using namespace Rcpp;

// [[Rcpp::export]]
arma::mat eigen_sym_mat(const arma::mat& x) {
  arma::mat eigval = eig_sym(x);

  return eigval;
}

The benchmark results are:

Input Median time cpp11armadillo Median time RcppArmadillo Memory allocation cpp11armadillo Memory allocation RcppArmadillo
500x500 35.07ms 36.4ms 17.1KB 4.62MB
1000x1000 260.28ms 263.21ms 21KB 4.62MB
1500x1500 874.62ms 857.31ms 24.9KB 4.63MB
2000x2000 2.21s 2.21s 28.8KB 4.63MB

From the benchmark, it follows that the computation times are identical. Both libraries use Armadillo as a backend, and the marginal differences are because of how cpp11 and Rcpp pass data from R to C++ and viceversa.

Conclusion

RcppArmadillo has been and will continue to be widely successful. cpp11armadillo is a alternative templated implementation that chooses different design trade-offs and features. Both packages can co-exist and continue to enrich the R community.
